maybe misconceptions people have about conference talks I want to talk about some ideas of how you can come up with a topic for a conference talk And I want to give you some ideas of how the process works and how you can kind of work your way through it Some stuff I got from my experience of doing conference talks But before I do any of that I want to sell you on the idea I recognize not first one is you will learn things Every time you do a conference talk you're working out how to tell a story about something you've And you're working out how to communicate that to a whole load of that triggers new thoughts I'm like oh you know what I hadn't thought of that That's not something that would have occurred to me I have a talk that I've actually given quite a few times over the last year or so And it's actually changed from when I first gave it you can look at the video of that and the last time I gave it And the reason it's changed is because people had questions And they said you know what have you thought about doing it this way They've actually improved the It's like a better talk now than it was when I started Because I learn things So if you do conference talks you will learn things about the thing you talk about The other thing is or the next benefit is you will meet people who are interested in the same things you are To an extent we get that just by being here right We get this by being at the conference You get to meet people who are interested in containers and cloud native because that's why we're all here But if you're a speaker that gets even better Because you get questions right People will think to come ask you questions about your topic and you'll get to meet them You also get to meet your fellow speakers and conference organizers who are unsurprisingly interested in the same kind of things you are And it brings me to my half a A little secret about conference speaking Sometimes they give you free food You get speaker dinners And speaker dinners are great because you get to meet all the people you're speaking with and you get an opportunity to talk to them And they feed you for free which is awesome So that's another benefit You get free food And then there's a last benefit that I think I can give some examples of which it can help your It can be good for you to develop as people in a career in this field Because it turns out if you stand up on stage and you talk about a people will assume you know something about it Maybe not always true but they will assume it In a past life I was a security consultant and I did quite a lot of talks on various security topics And on more than one occasion I've had people come up to me after the talk and say hey you know something about this Great Would you bid for this piece of work So as a consultant I've got work I even once developed and delivered a training course off a KubeCon talk In the early days of KubeCon it was 2018 I did a talk on security Not a lot of people were talking about it back then so some company came up and hey you know something about this Could you do training for us Which I did And that was really cool It was really kind of very interesting You can even change your whole career path by doing conference talks So the last two roles I've got I got directly as a result of having done conference talks and having written about the topic of container security About four years ago it was actually one of the other speakers who was on yesterday approached me and said hey Rory you like doing talks about container security Do you want to do complete coincidence this is me 16 years ago doing a talk about web application security at Scotland on Rails 2009 in this very venue So it's a complete full circle I came back to the same place I did you go about it How do you get started The first thing is come up with an Think about something and I'm going to say think of something that's interesting to you because conference talks and developing a talk is a bit of work Don't do something boring because if you do something boring you're going to hate yourself by the time especially if you get accepted and then you're like oh I actually have to do the work now If it's boring you're going to hate yourself by the time you finish So pick something you like something you enjoy something you actively like thinking about And then there are security people and your story might be interesting to different groups Then you want to find a venue right You want to give somewhere to give your talk and it doesn't just have to be somewhere that's often quite frequent as well so you don't have to wait a whole year for a conference to come around And also a little secret about user groups they're always looking for Every single user group I know of is always looking for new speakers The reason I was able to give talks at a conference was I actually ran a user group for the Open Web Application Security Project back in Edinburgh in the mid 2000s and I had to give quite a lot of talks to fill in the I couldn't get enough people to do so I per force ended up doing it There is CloudNative Edinburgh and I did ask and they are looking for So if you're I've got an idea there's an opportunity for you They meet regularly similar kind of people to this and you could give your talk there So that's a great place to start But you might think well Rory you said conference talks and I want to do conference talks Now we're heading towards Halloween fairly obviously so let's talk about something scary or something people think is scary Call for papers CFPs if you want to do a conference talk you almost inevitably will have to submit your talk to a call for And people can get a bit intimidated about these so I'm going to explain how they work and why you don't need to worry and don't be scared about them at all really So a CFP works essentially it's how conferences get their They put up a and then they say here give us the and we'll look at doing your talk There are lots and lots of these because there are lots of and they are all different So what you want to do is you want to identify conferences that are the kind of place you want to give your talk There are some websites I've linked some I've got a resources slide at the end there are some links there there are lots of websites that accumulate all of these now and there are many many many many conferences so there's lots of opportunities You want to watch out for when they open their CFP because some places will open their CFP 11 months before the and then they'll close it like nine months before the As if you're on socials you'll see people talk about KubeCon because KubeCon does its CFP a long way in advance Other places the CFP will still be open three weeks before the I have seen that happen that was perhaps a little bit late for them But it's very variable So you will get this conference identify the one you want to speak at then you want to fill in the CFP Now some of them this is a bit weird some of them will say I want 100 words right All you can give us is 100 words That's your abstract and that's all we want to see Other places want like white papers they want like learning outcomes they want all sorts of So be a bit aware of the conference you want to submit to they are very variable And the thing you want to do is you want a title and an abstract at a bare minimum And what you're doing here is selling your talk You're selling your talk to the conference organizers you're selling your talk to the people who are going to come and see it Because if you looked at the program I'm sure you have for today and for what did you read You read the What did you make you decide which talk to go and see The abstract You're selling your talk So you want to make sure it's good and it actually describes the story you want to And at this point it being 2025 I'm not allowed to do a talk without mentioning AI at least once So I will Because it turns out the LLMs are really good at writing conference talk titles and abstracts This isn't a surprise when you think about it because they've sucked in every successful talk and abstract that's ever been given as part of their training data So it turns out they can spit those things out And I'm going to say now very clearly do not let a LLM write your conference abstract Because if you let it write it will if you ask it You could literally just say I want to do a talk about Kubernetes modernization give me an abstract It totally will Don't do it Because that is the LLM's story That is its experience And if I want to know its experience I'll ask it I don't need to go to a conference talk We want to hear your experiences We want to hear your what you've learned what you've Now that's not to say don't use them at all Because again 2025 you can't avoid them But you can use them in an intelligent and clever way One of the things I use them for is I'll work out my I'll work out what I want to say And then I'll give it to an LLM and say give me some ideas for I'm not great at And they are And it'll come up with some And I generally go yep that one's not bad I'll just play with it I'll tweak it a little bit So I'm not saying don't use them And there are also you can use them to help you like polish up the words Be a little careful with allowing it toward everything Because conference organizers are getting inundated with things generated by LLMs And it turns out you can kind of tell by the way they write sometimes And that can be seen as like is this your idea Or is it the LLMs But you can work intelligently with them to improve things And I actually linked a blog at the end by my colleague Whitney The CNCF blog I've long an excellent in depth guide to how you can work with them to improve your conference submissions So you're going to submit your talk to And then you're going to And you're going to And you're going to And sometimes you wait so long that you'll forget you submitted to the I have done this I once got accepted and I had to ask them what it was I'd submitted Because that's the challenge of doing a lot of Kind of because it's my job I do quite a few of them So sometimes I might forget what exactly I submitted to a given conference And you'll wait for a long time And eventually you will get the response back about whether you have been successful And sometimes you will be rejected by the Don't worry Everyone and I do mean everyone who does this a gets rejected by conference CFPs all the time I got rejected by two last month That's fine It's not a It doesn't mean your talk was bad What it means is they were very busy They got 10 times the number of submissions as they have talk slots They got a lot of talks on a similar topic And they had to choose one because they can't give all the talks on the same topic because people don't want to see that Or maybe they couldn't quite understand what your talk was trying to do And one of the things I recommend is if you put in a talk submission and you don't get accepted ask for Ask them why Now conference organizers are very busy No doubt But I've had good success And I will ask especially if it's a new talk I've not given before I'll say hey this wasn't successful Good luck with the conference But can you give me any Why didn't this work And I've had very interesting feedback Sometimes it has been literally I didn't explain it well I didn't make a good enough case for why my talk was something they would want to put on at their conference Sometimes was it just a bad fit This talk isn't right for this specific audience That's fine Just a process of saying okay there's almost another conference This is actually a lot easier than it used to be Now there's many many conferences There's conferences all over the place all over the UK all over Europe all the time Find another event Find another venue Maybe tweak up the submission I've had a couple where I've done them three or four times They didn't get accepted anywhere I was like okay less interesting than I thought it was That's fine Think of another idea and submit it there And eventually you'll get a talk accepted And then comes the fun part of actually designing and setting up the  I don't have another hour or to go through all of that But there are some good resources I've linked again in the last slide I've linked some videos by another one of my who did some good videos about how to do conference talks There are lots of resources out there There are lots of things you can look at that will tell you how to do a good conference talk But once you've got it then comes the fun part You get to stand up here So conclusion Anyone can give a talk The more different types of people we get up on stage the better Because the more interesting and cool experiences we will hear Everyone has something to talk about You're sitting there You do have something you can do a conference talk on And I thoroughly hope that we will see some people from the on stage at next year's KCD UK Resources are in the Feel free to click the QR code And I hope that's been interesting
